BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 15, 1915.

FIFTH REGIMENT MEET SATURDAY

JOHNS HOPKINS-FIFTH REGIMENT
Tait and Tressider, Olympic Stars, to Be
Among Large Number of Entrants in
Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Games.

The Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment track meet, to be held Saturday at the Fifth Regiment Armory,
promises to outshine any meet of
previous years.
Runners from the University of
Virginia, Washington and Lee, St.
John's, Maryland Aggies, Penn
State, George Washington, Catholic University, Mount St. Mary's,
Lebanon Valley, Georgetown and a
number of other colleges and universities will be entered.
The last event on the program,
and to Hopkins the one of greatest
interest, will be the mile relay for
the South Atlantic Intercollegiate
Indoor Championship. The 'Varsity will compete against relays
from Virginia, Washington and Lee
and Georgetown. This promises to
be a close race. All Hopkins men
should be together before this race
to cheer the four Black and Blue
runners. The best place to assemble is near the finish line.
Next to the relay, interest will
center about Tait and Tressider,
two Olympic men, who have entered the races. Several years ago
Baltimore people saw Tressider run
three miles against a relay team of
three, each running a mile. Tressider had little trouble in winning
this race, and if he shows anywhere near his old form the spectators can look for a spectacular performance.
The management is preparing to
handle the large crowd that is expected to attend the games. All
the ushers will be Hopkins men,
while the officials of the meet will
be selected from some of the bestknown men interested in athletics
in the country.
Hopkins has entered a large
squad and is prepared to fight to a
finish for every point. All Hopkins
students should be there to cheer
the team.
The following is a list of the
Hopkins entrants:
Ioo-Yard Dash — Sutton, Wiggins, Wright, Larcus, I3inford,
Dempster, Pfitsch, Penniman,
Martz, Phondson, Golder, Marcus,
Rusk, Weeks, Winchester, Perkins,
Brower, Edgett, Fisher, Darley and
Jarrett.
220-Yard Dash — Sutton, Wiggins, Wright, Dempster, G. Hall,
Pfitsch, Wells, Straus and Penniman.
440-Yards—Larcus, Dempster, F.
Hall, G. Hall, Wells, Merrick, Penniman, Straus, Uhler and Marcus.
88o Yards — F. Hall, Hutton,
errick, Spencer and Uhler.

MUSICAL CLUBS SCORE TRIUMPH

BASEBALL TO ORGANIZE FRIDAY

McCoy Hall Concert Featured by Excellent Work of Glee and Instrumental
Clubs Soloists and Quartet Star.

Coach Hooper Will Assemble Candidates
to Formally Inaugurate Sport for This
Spring--Advisers to Speak.

The McCoy Hall concert of the
'Varsity Glee and Instrumental
Clubs last Tuesday night gave ample evidence of the fact that the
Johns Hopkins musicians are this
year in better form than ever before. The concert was throughout
marked by excellent work by both
clubs and deserves to be accredited
with the title "best yet."
The Instrumental Club is by far
the best that Hopkins has ever
turned out; under the leadership
of Walter F. Geissel, the musicians
have reached a standard of efficiency
higher than that of any similar organization of past years. In fact,
one outsider who was present at
the cOncert said that they played
as well as any of the clubs of the
big colleges of this country, all of
which he had heard. The Glee
Club also set a precedent as being
the best that Hopkins has ever produced.
One of the features of the evening was a humorous sketch billed
under the title, "The Bostadelphia
Sympathy Band," which was given
by six of the comedians of the
clubs. This act brought down the
house.
The Instrumental Club was best
heard in the selections from "Sari"
and "High Jinks," and the "Aba
Da b a Honeymoon." The men
played together remarkably well
and received more than the usual
share of applause. The Glee Club
was at its best is "The Mulligan
Musketeers" and "Drink to Me
Only With Thine Eyes."
Mr. Geissel, as violin soloist,
played with evident authority and
feeling, showinfr a well-balanced
technical and artistic mastery of his
instrument. Mr. Gminder, who is
well known ainong the younger artists of this city, played GabrielMaria's"Serenade Badine" in a manner which would have done much
credit to a mature artist. Mr. Gminder is a 'cellist of known ability and
his solos at Musical Club concerts are
always received with enthusiasm.
Mr. B. r. Spieker, the leader of

The organization meeting of the
baseball team will be held at five
o'clock Friday afternoon in the
Trophy Room.
After a preliminary study of the
material available this spring, Coach
Hooper has expressed the belief
that there are prospects for an unusually well-balanced team.. Over
half of last year's 'Varsity men remain in the University, and there
is a large number of new men who
have had experience at the game.
In spite of this bright outlook for
a successful nine, Coach Hooper
wants it understood that he needs
at least thirty new men in his squad,
for he will have to train men to
take the places of the number who
will graduate this year. For this
reason he wants everyone interested
in baseball to attend the organization meeting and join the squad.
• The day after organization (Saturday) practice will begin in the
cage. The practice days will be
Tuesdays and Thursdays at four
o'clock, and Saturdays at 2.30
o'clock. Work will be done in the
cage until weather permits the use
of the auxiliary field at Homewood,
and when the squad moves outdoors, practices will be held daily.
It was decided to delay the organization meeting this year because of tile desire to lessen the
amount of work done in the cage.
It has always been considered
dangerous to be in the small enclosure with balls being batted in
every direction, and this year that
character of work will be reserved
for outdoor practices. The cage
work will consist simply of "warming up" exercises.
The speakers at the organization
meeting will be Coach Eddie Hooper the team's advisers, Dr. Thomas
R. Brown, pr. Robert B. Roulston
and Mr. Robertson Griswold: Dr.
Ronald T. Abercrombie, Captain
C. C. Porter and Manager J. S.
Short.
Mr. Kistler has consented to allow his freshman gymnasium class
to attend the baseball meeting, but
wants the men to report to him at

Charlie Brickle , one of the most
famous football players who ever
handled the pigskin, has been selected as the coach of the Johns
liopkins football team for the sea-;on of 1915. At the meeting of the
football advisers'on Saturday afternoon Brickley's name was put up
for consideration, with the immediate result that he was chosen as
the best man to take care of the
squad next fall.
The coming of Brickley to coach
I Iopkins will undoubtedly mark the
beginning of a new epoch in the
history of Black and Blue football
teams. With a man of the calibre
that Brickley has proven himself
to be at the head of affairs, interest
in football at Johns Hopkins will
he greater than it has been at any
other time since the beginning of
athletics at the University; outsiders interested in football generally
will follow the progress of the team
on account of the fame of the coach,
and Hopkins men will come out for
the team with twice the usual enthusiasm and eagerness to make
good, for to come into direct contact
with a man who .has mastered the
game in such a brilliant manner as
Brickley has, is an exceptional privilege, one which can be claimed by
few football players as their own.
Brickley's reputation alone will
put football at Hopkins on a firm
foundation. The opportunity to he
coached by the former Harvard
captain should draw many able
players to become students of the
University, and the number of candidates for next season's team
promises to outclass the support
given the activity at any previous
time. The chances for the development of a strong team will be
doubly large.
If now, together with the services of Brickley as coach, a means
can be found whereby the squad
may have opportunity to practice
more in the afternoon, the condition of football affairs at Hopkins
will be ideal. • If Brickley's coaching ability measures up in any way
to his ability at a player, and the
team can have good material, tog-ether with ample time for practice, there is no reason why the
Black and Blue eleven should not
be put well on the road to developing into a machine which will be
able to cope successfully with the
teams of the larger colleges.

Tryouts for the 'Varsity debating teams that will meet the representatives of the Universities of
Virginia and North Carolina on
April 24 were held at one o'clock
last Wednesday in the main assembly hall.
Each candidate for a position on
the teams was questioned at some
length in regard to various phases
of the subject to be discussed, in
order that his degree of facility in
refutation might be determined.
Those finally chosen by Dr. French
to act as three of the four speakers representing Hopkins were
Avra M. Warren, Charles S. Weech
and Thomas J. Tingley. It is the
hope of Dr. French, and of all who
are interested in Hopkins debating,
that Albert L. Hammond, who is
engaged in pursuing graduate studies and in teaching classes in Public Speaking I at the University,
may be adjudged by the other institutions concerned as eligible for
the fourth speakership. Both Virginia and North Carolina have relied somewhat heavily on the efforts
of graduate students in the past,
but the fact that Mr. Hammond is
an instructor in public speaking is
a complicating factor in the problem of his eligibility. Alfred S.
Niles, Jr., and Moses Baroway were
selected by Dr. French to act in the
capacity of advisers or of alternates
for the teams.
The number of men to compete
for the speakership was rather disappointing, the interest displayed in
the debate being by no means equal
to that manifested in former years.
This 'scarcity of candidates was
more than atoned for, however, by
the quality of the work done by
those who took part in the tryouts,
and there is every reason to believe
that the men chosen to debate for
Hopkins will be able to sustain the
hard pace that has been set by their
victorious predecessors in the two
years that the "triangle" has been
in existence.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 15, 1915.
PRES. BUTLER TO BE ORATOR

PEACE CONTEST TO BE HELD

SPECIAL OFFER to Professors and Students.

REBUILT VISIBLE HAMMOND TYPEWRITERS
Columbia Executive Will Make Principal
Address at Celebration of University's Founding Next Monday.

Local Men to Compete in Preliminary
Contest on Tuesday, Feb. 23, at
12.50 P.M.,in McCoy Hall.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler,
president of Columbia University,
will be the orator at the thirtyninth Commemoration Day exercises, which will be celebrated in
McCoy Hall on Washington's Birthday. The subject of his address
has not been made known, but his
prominence as an educator and
speaker has created an interest
which presages the attendance of
an unusually large audience.
President Goodnow, whose selection as president of the University
was announced officially at the
Commemoration Day exercises on
last February 22, will preside, and
much interest will be attached to
his "University announcements,"
for it is thought that something
will be said of Homewood. The
selection of Dr. Goodnow as president was told by Dr. William H.
Welch last year under the subject
of "University announcements," and
it is probable that the new executive will take this opportunity to
tell of his study so far of the
"Homewood problem."
The exercises will begin at I I
o'clock. A half hour earlier the
trustees, the faculty in caps and
gowns and the students will form
in academic. procession, and, led by
Dr. Butler and Dr. Goodnow, will
march into the hall. An elaborate
musical program will be played under the direction of Mr. E. L.
Turnbull. There will be no classes
on the day of the exercises.
The alumni banquet, which will
be held on Monday night will close
this interesting day. Speeches will
be made by Dr. Theodore C. Janeway, one of the professors of the
William H. Welch Foundation; the
Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte, attorney-general of the Roosevelt cabinet and Mr. Gustav L. Stewart,
chairman of the committee of alumni athletic advisers.
Mr. Stewart will speak on
"Johns Hopkins Athletics"—a topic
that will prove especially interesting
to many of the alumni who are
showing renewed interest in the
University's sports. Mr. Stewart
has been unusually interested and
active this year in working for the
welfare of athletics and his intimate
connection with the situation will
furnish an excellent position from
which to draw the material for his
talk.
Dr. Thomas R. Brown, president
of the Alumni Association, will act
s toastmaster.

The fifth annual contest of the
Intercollegiate Peace Association
will be held in McCoy Hall on Friday, March 19, at 8 o'clock P. M.
One prize of seventy-five dollars
is offered by the Maryland Peace
Society through its president, Mr.
Theodore Marburg.
The rules of the Association require each competing college to hold
a preliminary local contest in which
at least three speakers shall take
part. Such a local contest will be
held at Johns Hopkins on Tuesday,
February 23, at 12.50 P. M. in McHall.
Orations in this preliminary trial
will be limited to eight minutes. In
the State contest they must not exceed sixteen minutes. The subject
must be some aspect of international peace, and the oration must
be original. An oration previously
delivered in any other oratorical
contest is not available.
The winner of the Maryland and
District of Columbia contest of
March 19 will gain, besides the
prize of seventy-five dollars in gold,
the privilege of representing the
State and the District in the group
contest of the South Atlantic States.
Should he win in the group contest, he will represent his section
in the final contest at the Lake Mohonk Conference in May. The
South Atlantic group includes
Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia,
North Carolina and South Carolina.

SWIMMERS' GOOD SCHEDULE;
BRINTON ELECTED MANAGER

The swimming team is working
hard in preparation for two of the
most important meets of the year,
with Navy on Saturday at Annapolis, and with Swarthmore a week
later at Swarthmore, Pa. The men
are showing good form, and Captain Rowland is confident that the
independents will make a capable
showing.
Navy is represented by one of the
strongest teams in the East, and
if the Black and Blue squad succeeds in winning a few first places
it will be an accomplishment worthy
of note. Swarthmore, on the other
hand, is due for a second •beating
unless present speculations go entirely wrong. A victory over the
Pennsylvanians would undoubtedly
do much to boost the swimming
game at Hopkins.
Wilmer Brinton, '15, has been
chosen to succeed Dorsey Richardson as manager. Brinton has entered upon his duties with much
spirit, having closed for the Navy
and Swarthmore meets and opened
negotiations with Princeton and
Haverford College. Tf possible, the
latter squad will be met the night
previous to the Swarthmore meet,
making- the Pennsylvania trin of
two days' duration.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 15, 1915.
The Intercollegiate Peace Contests.

With the coming of the local contest of the Intercollegiate Peace Association, at which the man who is
to represent Johns Hopkins in the
State contest will be chosen, our attention is drawn to a phase of University activity, concerning which
there is a noticeable lack of information and interest among the students. Although they offer, besides
the chance of attaining to a position
of some distinction among American college students, the opportunity to win money prizes as a reward for successful effort put forth
in their behalf in past years, these
contests have not aroused the
amount of general interest that they
deserve.
Now is the time for students to
take hold of this opportunity by
trying out at the contest to be held
in the near future. The interesting character of this work is developed to a much greater extent
this year, owing to the influence of
the present war in Europe, and
there are openings for work of a
new type. Especially at this time
ought students come out and by encouraging competition help Hopkins to make as good a showing as
possible.
It is interesting to note that two
years ago the second prize in .t1:7
final contest at Lake Mohonk, at
which representatives from all sections of the country took part, was
won by Calvert Magruder, a Maryland man, of St. John's College.
Last year the final contest was won
by a student from the University of
Texas.

The Fifth Regiment Games.

All students of the University,
whether they are interested in track
and field athletics or not, should
not miss the opportunity to be afforded Saturday night in the Fifth
Regiment Armory, when the 'Varsity team and the regimental athletes will have as their guests and
opponents Olympic stars and runners and field men from the University of Virginia, Washington and
Lee, Georgetown, St. John's, the
Maryland Aggies, Penn State, Mt.
St. Mary's, George Washington,
Catholic University, Lebanon Valley, and a number of other colleges
and universities.
This meet, the Baltimore track
classic, should attract every man in
the University, for it is the biggest
thing Hopkins does athletically during the year. On a single night
Hopkins summons to this city the
cream of athletes from nearby and
distant colleges and cities. It is
one of the events of greatest interest on the track schedule, and
is the chief meet of the indoor
season. Hopkins track and field
men regard it as their first great
test, for they will compete with
the best men south of New York.
And for these reasons the entire
student body should support its representatives on the floor that night.
There should be a cheering section
as large as that at the St. John's
football game. The track team and
the Fifth Regiment are offering the
city an opportunity to see the best
runners and track men in this section of the country. Every Hopkins man should back this enterprise
with his attendance and support the
'Varsity team from the cheering
stand.
BRICKLEY WILL COACH JOHNS HOPKINS
(Continued from page 1.)

Bricklev's contract will be for
one year only, but if he is able to
do what followers of the game believe he can do. he will undoubted'y
be retained. With the promise of
such events as must seemingly be
certain to follow his influence ol
Hopkins football, the outlook for
the future of the game here becomes very bright, and the possibility for future elevens to do
something worth while seems very
real.

MISSION STUDY CLASSES
ORGANIZED BY Y. M. C. A.

PROFESSOR WALLIS LECTURES
ON HIGHER BIBLICAL CRITICISM

Two Mission Study classes have
been organized by the University
Young Men's Christian Association.
Several meetings have already been
held.
Mr. Youel B. Mirza, a graduate
student in political science, is the
leader of a class in "Mohammed
and Mohammedanism." The textbook used is "Iran and Iranians,"
of which Mr. Mirza is the author.
The class meets every Wednesday
at one o'clock.
This course has proved very attractive and popular among the
students, if the attendance, while
not unusually large, may be taken
as an indication.
The other class, which holds its
meetings at one o'clock every
Thursday, has for its subject,
"Japan." Mr. James Fullerton
Gressitt, an alumnus and former
Y. M. C. A. secretary of this University, has charge of the class. Mr.
Gressitt, having spent the past
seven years in Japan as an educational missionary, is unusually well
equipped to make this a most interesting and instructive course.
Another class for which the officers of the Association hope to
have arrangements soon completed
will be on "North American Problems." The leader will be Mr.
William 0. Weyforth, Jr., who is
a graduate student in political science. "Christianity and Popular
Amusements" will be the text-book
use. More complete information
concerning this class will be given
later.
The Association earnestly invites
all members of the University to
join one of these classes with the
feeling that the student will derive
a great benefit along educational
and religious lines.
The attendance has been very encouraging in view of the recent
organization. However, the Officers
anticipate a decided improvement
in this direction.
The annual Maryland Intercollegiate Missionary Conference will
hold its opening meeting on the
evening of the twenty-sixth of this
month at Goucher College. All
colleges and universities in this
State will send delegates to this
conference, and Secretary Sutton
hopes that Hopkins will be represented creditably and requests that
all men interested should confer
with him as soon as possible.
A fee of one dollar is required
of all delegates to pay the expenses
of the Conference. The meetings,
however, will be open to the public
and one need not he a delegate to
attend.

Prof. Louis Wallis, of Chicago,
who has recently been speaking on
the single tax at various places in
Baltimore, addressed a large audience last Monday night in McCoy Hall on the subject of "Higher
Biblical Criticism."
Professor Wallis gave his view
of the Bible, showing that the Hebrew, and later the Christian religion, has been the enemy of
special privilege and has stood for
justice to the lower classes. The
fight of the Church in the past has
been between Ritual and Justice,
he said; that of the present Church
is between individual worship and
social justice.
After he had finished, counter
arguments were advanced by Dr.
Kelly and Dr. White, of New York,
maintaining the distinction between
economics and religion. A general
discussion ensued, in which most
of the topics of the higher Biblical
criticism were considered.

SUMMER SCHOOL WILL OFFER
COURSES IN GRADUATE WORK

Preparations for the courses to
be given in the fifth year of the
Johns Hopkins Summer School are
already being made, and although
the descriptive catalog will not be
ready before March 1, one important innovation has been announced
in advance.
This innovation, a provision for
graduate courses in the Summer
School, is commented upon in an
editorial in the last edition of the
Alumni Magazine as being the first
to be introduced by the new administration, and as a significant indication of the progressive policy that
is being followed in the carrying on
of University affairs. These courses
are offered in partial fulfillment of
the requirements for the degree of
master of arts. Thus attendance
upon graduate courses in the Summer School for three years will be
considered as a substitute for one
of the two years of study formerly
required of candidates for a master's degree by the Board of University Studies.
The number of departments which
will be included under the provisions of this new arrangement has
not yet been finally decided upon,
but every effort will be made to
provide instruction in every department that is desired by enough students to make up a class of appreciable size. All who are interested in the formation of classes
are therefore requested to communicate with Dr. E. F. Buchner,
who will this season again be the
director of the summer courses.
The plans at present under consideration provide for the extension of
this new policy into ten branches
of graduate study.
The other courses given will be
to a large extent the same that have
proven so very popular in the previous years of the Summer School's
existence. As in the case of graduate studies, special arrangements
will be made for classes desiring to
pursue other studies than those
offered in the regular curriculum.
A full description of the work to
be covered will be found in the
prospectus which will be issued in
the course of the nekt few weeks.

Professor J. M. Vincent, who is
in charge of the contest for the
Tocqueville medal, has recently
drawn attention to the fact that
little over two months remain before all essays must be handed in.
Dr. Vincent expressed the hope that
this year more interest would be
taken in this competition.
The Tocqueville gold medal is
annually given to the Johns Hopkins University by the Baron Pierre
de Coubertin, of Paris, and it is
offered by the University to that
student who shall have written the
!pest essay on sonic subject illustrating any phase of French history,
political or social, from 1815 to
1890, or a review of some important historical work published in
France since 1890.
Participation in this contest is
confined to undergraduates. Since
the abandonment of the compulsory
essay for graduation, the number
of contestants has never been very
large. Essays must be either printed,
legibly written, or typewritten (on
one side of ordinary thesis-sized

HULLABALOO BOARD IS BUSY
HANDLING ITS CONTRIBUTIONS

MILITARY INSTRUCTION CAMPS
TO BE HELD FOR COLLEGE MEN

During the past week the Hullabaloo Board has had four meetings. These were found to be
necessary to handle the amount of
work with which the Board has
been swamped. On Tuesdays the
Board meets to look over articles
that have been worked up by the
editors during the daily meetings.
So far cuts have been made of
many of the pictures that were
taken earlier in the year. Since
everything will have to be ready for
press within about four or five
Weeks, those who have not ordered
their books had better do so, because the number of books this year
is going to be limited. Anyone
wishing to subscribe may obtain
blanks from any member of the
Board.
This year the book will contain
a number of surprises in the way
of unusual pictures of the University life. The art department has
received some contributions from
some of the members of the other
classes, but it still needs much
more material.
Business Manager Spencer announces that he is fairly well
pleased with the number of subscriptions, but he thinks that the
circulation among the freshmen
class ought to be larger. From
this year on the Board wants the
Hullabaloo to be more of a University book and not so much of
a class book as the former Hullabaloos have been. If each class in
the University will get behind this
book it must certainly be a success.

The Society of the National Reserve Corps has recently launched
a nation-wide campaign among
American colleges to arouse interest in the Government's Student's Military Instruction Camps;
and, among the others, Hopkins
men have been asked to furnish
their quota for the furtherance of
this movement.
The object of the Corps is to
give the young men of the country
opportunity for a short course in
military training. The summer vacation period is selected to enable
students to attend with the least
inconvenience and greatest instructional advantage.
The benefit of these camps to
the nation is that they foster a
patriotic spirit, and spread among
the citizens of the country a more
thorough knowledge of military history, military policy and military
needs. The benefit to the student
is that these camps are certain to
increase his business efficiency, and
hence his economic value through
the habits thus acquired of discipline, obedience, self-control, order,
and command, and the study of
organization and administration as
exemplified in first-class modern
armies.
Now that the country has been
aroused to the fact that the state
of defence of the nation is inadequate, these camps take on especial
importance as furnishing a means
by which a large and well trained
citizen reserve may be built up.
The requisites for admission to
the camps are that students must

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 15, 1915.

FIFTH REGIMENT MEET SATURDAY

JOHNS HOPKINS-FIFTH REGIMENT
Tait and Tressider, Olympic Stars, to Be
Among Large Number of Entrants in
Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Games.

The Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment track meet, to be held Saturday at the Fifth Regiment Armory,
promises to outshine any meet of
previous years.
Runners from the University of
Virginia, Washington and Lee, St.
John's, Maryland Aggies, Penn
State, George Washington, Catholic University, Mount St. Mary's,
Lebanon Valley, Georgetown and a
number of other colleges and universities will be entered.
The last event on the program,
and to Hopkins the one of greatest
interest, will be the mile relay for
the South Atlantic Intercollegiate
Indoor Championship. The 'Varsity will compete against relays
from Virginia, Washington and Lee
and Georgetown. This promises to
be a close race. All Hopkins men
should be together before this race
to cheer the four Black and Blue
runners. The best place to assemble is near the finish line.
Next to the relay, interest will
center about Tait and Tressider,
two Olympic men, who have entered the races. Several years ago
Baltimore people saw Tressider run
three miles against a relay team of
three, each running a mile. Tressider had little trouble in winning
this race, and if he shows anywhere near his old form the spectators can look for a spectacular performance.
The management is preparing to
handle the large crowd that is expected to attend the games. All
the ushers will be Hopkins men,
while the officials of the meet will
be selected from some of the bestknown men interested in athletics
in the country.
Hopkins has entered a large
squad and is prepared to fight to a
finish for every point. All Hopkins
students should be there to cheer
the team.
The following is a list of the
Hopkins entrants:

MUSICAL CLUBS SCORE TRIUMPH

BASEBALL TO ORGANIZE FRIDAY

McCoy Hall Concert Featured by Excellent Work of Glee and Instrumental
Clubs Soloists and Quartet Star.

Coach Hooper Will Assemble Candidates
to Formally Inaugurate Sport for This
Spring--Advisers to Speak.

The McCoy Hall concert of the
'Varsity Glee and Instrumental
Clubs last Tuesday night gave ample evidence of the fact that the
Johns Hopkins musicians are this
year in better form than ever before. The concert was throughout
marked by excellent work by both
clubs and deserves to be accredited
with the title "best yet."
The Instrumental Club is by far
the best that Hopkins has ever
turned out; under the leadership
of Walter F. Geissel, the musicians
have reached a standard of efficiency
higher than that of any similar organization of past years. In fact,
one outsider who was present at
the cOncert said that they played
as well as any of the clubs of the
big colleges of this country, all of
which he had heard. The Glee
Club also set a precedent as being
the best that Hopkins has ever produced.
One of the features of the evening was a humorous sketch billed
under the title, "The Bostadelphia
Sympathy Band," which was given
by six of the comedians of the
clubs. This act brought down the
house.
The Instrumental Club was best
heard in the selections from "Sari"
and "High Jinks," and the "Aba
Da b a Honeymoon." The men
played together remarkably well
and received more than the usual
share of applause. The Glee Club
was at its best is "The Mulligan
Musketeers" and "Drink to Me
Only With Thine Eyes."
Mr. Geissel, as violin soloist,
played with evident authority and
feeling, showinfr a well-balanced
technical and artistic mastery of his
instrument. Mr. Gminder, who is
well known ainong the younger artists of this city, played GabrielMaria's"Serenade Badine" in a manner which would have done much
credit to a mature artist. Mr. Gminder is a 'cellist of known ability and
his solos at Musical Club concerts are
always received with enthusiasm.

The organization meeting of the
baseball team will be held at five
o'clock Friday afternoon in the
Trophy Room.
After a preliminary study of the
material available this spring, Coach
Hooper has expressed the belief
that there are prospects for an unusually well-balanced team.. Over
half of last year's 'Varsity men remain in the University, and there
is a large number of new men who
have had experience at the game.
In spite of this bright outlook for
a successful nine, Coach Hooper
wants it understood that he needs
at least thirty new men in his squad,
for he will have to train men to
take the places of the number who
will graduate this year. For this
reason he wants everyone interested
in baseball to attend the organization meeting and join the squad.
• The day after organization (Saturday) practice will begin in the
cage. The practice days will be
Tuesdays and Thursdays at four
o'clock, and Saturdays at 2.30
o'clock. Work will be done in the
cage until weather permits the use
of the auxiliary field at Homewood,
and when the squad moves outdoors, practices will be held daily.
It was decided to delay the organization meeting this year because of tile desire to lessen the
amount of work done in the cage.
It has always been considered
dangerous to be in the small enclosure with balls being batted in
every direction, and this year that
character of work will be reserved
for outdoor practices. The cage
work will consist simply of "warming up" exercises.
The speakers at the organization
meeting will be Coach Eddie Hooper the team's advisers, Dr. Thomas
R. Brown, pr. Robert B. Roulston
and Mr. Robertson Griswold: Dr.
Ronald T. Abercrombie, Captain
C. C. Porter and Manager J. S.
Short.
Mr. Kistler has consented to allow his freshman gymnasium class
to attend the baseball meeting, but
wants the men to report to him at

Charlie Brickle , one of the most
famous football players who ever
handled the pigskin, has been selected as the coach of the Johns
liopkins football team for the sea-;on of 1915. At the meeting of the
football advisers'on Saturday afternoon Brickley's name was put up
for consideration, with the immediate result that he was chosen as
the best man to take care of the
squad next fall.
The coming of Brickley to coach
I Iopkins will undoubtedly mark the
beginning of a new epoch in the
history of Black and Blue football
teams. With a man of the calibre
that Brickley has proven himself
to be at the head of affairs, interest
in football at Johns Hopkins will
he greater than it has been at any
other time since the beginning of
athletics at the University; outsiders interested in football generally
will follow the progress of the team
on account of the fame of the coach,
and Hopkins men will come out for
the team with twice the usual enthusiasm and eagerness to make
good, for to come into direct contact
with a man who .has mastered the
game in such a brilliant manner as
Brickley has, is an exceptional privilege, one which can be claimed by
few football players as their own.
Brickley's reputation alone will
put football at Hopkins on a firm
foundation. The opportunity to he
coached by the former Harvard
captain should draw many able
players to become students of the
University, and the number of candidates for next season's team
promises to outclass the support
given the activity at any previous
time. The chances for the development of a strong team will be
doubly large.
If now, together with the services of Brickley as coach, a means
can be found whereby the squad
may have opportunity to practice
more in the afternoon, the condition of football affairs at Hopkins
will be ideal. • If Brickley's coaching ability measures up in any way
to his ability at a player, and the
team can have good material, tog-ether with ample time for practice, there is no reason why the
Black and Blue eleven should not
be put well on the road to developing into a machine which will be
able to cope successfully with the
teams of the larger colleges.

Tryouts for the 'Varsity debating teams that will meet the representatives of the Universities of
Virginia and North Carolina on
April 24 were held at one o'clock
last Wednesday in the main assembly hall.
Each candidate for a position on
the teams was questioned at some
length in regard to various phases
of the subject to be discussed, in
order that his degree of facility in
refutation might be determined.
Those finally chosen by Dr. French
to act as three of the four speakers representing Hopkins were
Avra M. Warren, Charles S. Weech
and Thomas J. Tingley. It is the
hope of Dr. French, and of all who
are interested in Hopkins debating,
that Albert L. Hammond, who is
engaged in pursuing graduate studies and in teaching classes in Public Speaking I at the University,
may be adjudged by the other institutions concerned as eligible for
the fourth speakership. Both Virginia and North Carolina have relied somewhat heavily on the efforts
of graduate students in the past,
but the fact that Mr. Hammond is
an instructor in public speaking is
a complicating factor in the problem of his eligibility. Alfred S.
Niles, Jr., and Moses Baroway were
selected by Dr. French to act in the
capacity of advisers or of alternates
for the teams.
The number of men to compete
for the speakership was rather disappointing, the interest displayed in
the debate being by no means equal
to that manifested in former years.
This 'scarcity of candidates was
more than atoned for, however, by
the quality of the work done by
those who took part in the tryouts,
and there is every reason to believe
that the men chosen to debate for
Hopkins will be able to sustain the
hard pace that has been set by their
victorious predecessors in the two
years that the "triangle" has been
in existence.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 15, 1915.
PRES. BUTLER TO BE ORATOR

PEACE CONTEST TO BE HELD

SPECIAL OFFER to Professors and Students.

REBUILT VISIBLE HAMMOND TYPEWRITERS
Columbia Executive Will Make Principal
Address at Celebration of University's Founding Next Monday.

Local Men to Compete in Preliminary
Contest on Tuesday, Feb. 23, at
12.50 P.M.,in McCoy Hall.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler,
president of Columbia University,
will be the orator at the thirtyninth Commemoration Day exercises, which will be celebrated in
McCoy Hall on Washington's Birthday. The subject of his address
has not been made known, but his
prominence as an educator and
speaker has created an interest
which presages the attendance of
an unusually large audience.
President Goodnow, whose selection as president of the University
was announced officially at the
Commemoration Day exercises on
last February 22, will preside, and
much interest will be attached to
his "University announcements,"
for it is thought that something
will be said of Homewood. The
selection of Dr. Goodnow as president was told by Dr. William H.
Welch last year under the subject
of "University announcements," and
it is probable that the new executive will take this opportunity to
tell of his study so far of the
"Homewood problem."
The exercises will begin at I I
o'clock. A half hour earlier the
trustees, the faculty in caps and
gowns and the students will form
in academic. procession, and, led by
Dr. Butler and Dr. Goodnow, will
march into the hall. An elaborate
musical program will be played under the direction of Mr. E. L.
Turnbull. There will be no classes
on the day of the exercises.
The alumni banquet, which will
be held on Monday night will close
this interesting day. Speeches will
be made by Dr. Theodore C. Janeway, one of the professors of the
William H. Welch Foundation; the
Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte, attorney-general of the Roosevelt cabinet and Mr. Gustav L. Stewart,
chairman of the committee of alumni athletic advisers.
Mr. Stewart will speak on
"Johns Hopkins Athletics"—a topic
that will prove especially interesting
to many of the alumni who are
showing renewed interest in the
University's sports. Mr. Stewart
has been unusually interested and
active this year in working for the
welfare of athletics and his intimate
connection with the situation will
furnish an excellent position from
which to draw the material for his
talk.
Dr. Thomas R. Brown, president
of the Alumni Association, will act
s toastmaster.

The fifth annual contest of the
Intercollegiate Peace Association
will be held in McCoy Hall on Friday, March 19, at 8 o'clock P. M.
One prize of seventy-five dollars
is offered by the Maryland Peace
Society through its president, Mr.
Theodore Marburg.
The rules of the Association require each competing college to hold
a preliminary local contest in which
at least three speakers shall take
part. Such a local contest will be
held at Johns Hopkins on Tuesday,
February 23, at 12.50 P. M. in McHall.
Orations in this preliminary trial
will be limited to eight minutes. In
the State contest they must not exceed sixteen minutes. The subject
must be some aspect of international peace, and the oration must
be original. An oration previously
delivered in any other oratorical
contest is not available.
The winner of the Maryland and
District of Columbia contest of
March 19 will gain, besides the
prize of seventy-five dollars in gold,
the privilege of representing the
State and the District in the group
contest of the South Atlantic States.
Should he win in the group contest, he will represent his section
in the final contest at the Lake Mohonk Conference in May. The
South Atlantic group includes
Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia,
North Carolina and South Carolina.

SWIMMERS' GOOD SCHEDULE;
BRINTON ELECTED MANAGER

The swimming team is working
hard in preparation for two of the
most important meets of the year,
with Navy on Saturday at Annapolis, and with Swarthmore a week
later at Swarthmore, Pa. The men
are showing good form, and Captain Rowland is confident that the
independents will make a capable
showing.
Navy is represented by one of the
strongest teams in the East, and
if the Black and Blue squad succeeds in winning a few first places
it will be an accomplishment worthy
of note. Swarthmore, on the other
hand, is due for a second •beating
unless present speculations go entirely wrong. A victory over the
Pennsylvanians would undoubtedly
do much to boost the swimming
game at Hopkins.
Wilmer Brinton, '15, has been
chosen to succeed Dorsey Richardson as manager. Brinton has entered upon his duties with much
spirit, having closed for the Navy
and Swarthmore meets and opened
negotiations with Princeton and
Haverford College. Tf possible, the
latter squad will be met the night
previous to the Swarthmore meet,
making- the Pennsylvania trin of
two days' duration.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 15, 1915.
The Intercollegiate Peace Contests.

With the coming of the local contest of the Intercollegiate Peace Association, at which the man who is
to represent Johns Hopkins in the
State contest will be chosen, our attention is drawn to a phase of University activity, concerning which
there is a noticeable lack of information and interest among the students. Although they offer, besides
the chance of attaining to a position
of some distinction among American college students, the opportunity to win money prizes as a reward for successful effort put forth
in their behalf in past years, these
contests have not aroused the
amount of general interest that they
deserve.
Now is the time for students to
take hold of this opportunity by
trying out at the contest to be held
in the near future. The interesting character of this work is developed to a much greater extent
this year, owing to the influence of
the present war in Europe, and
there are openings for work of a
new type. Especially at this time
ought students come out and by encouraging competition help Hopkins to make as good a showing as
possible.
It is interesting to note that two
years ago the second prize in .t1:7
final contest at Lake Mohonk, at
which representatives from all sections of the country took part, was
won by Calvert Magruder, a Maryland man, of St. John's College.
Last year the final contest was won
by a student from the University of
Texas.

The Fifth Regiment Games.

All students of the University,
whether they are interested in track
and field athletics or not, should
not miss the opportunity to be afforded Saturday night in the Fifth
Regiment Armory, when the 'Varsity team and the regimental athletes will have as their guests and
opponents Olympic stars and runners and field men from the University of Virginia, Washington and
Lee, Georgetown, St. John's, the
Maryland Aggies, Penn State, Mt.
St. Mary's, George Washington,
Catholic University, Lebanon Valley, and a number of other colleges
and universities.
This meet, the Baltimore track
classic, should attract every man in
the University, for it is the biggest
thing Hopkins does athletically during the year. On a single night
Hopkins summons to this city the
cream of athletes from nearby and
distant colleges and cities. It is
one of the events of greatest interest on the track schedule, and
is the chief meet of the indoor
season. Hopkins track and field
men regard it as their first great
test, for they will compete with
the best men south of New York.
And for these reasons the entire
student body should support its representatives on the floor that night.
There should be a cheering section
as large as that at the St. John's
football game. The track team and
the Fifth Regiment are offering the
city an opportunity to see the best
runners and track men in this section of the country. Every Hopkins man should back this enterprise
with his attendance and support the
'Varsity team from the cheering
stand.

MISSION STUDY CLASSES
ORGANIZED BY Y. M. C. A.

PROFESSOR WALLIS LECTURES
ON HIGHER BIBLICAL CRITICISM

Two Mission Study classes have
been organized by the University
Young Men's Christian Association.
Several meetings have already been
held.
Mr. Youel B. Mirza, a graduate
student in political science, is the
leader of a class in "Mohammed
and Mohammedanism." The textbook used is "Iran and Iranians,"
of which Mr. Mirza is the author.
The class meets every Wednesday
at one o'clock.
This course has proved very attractive and popular among the
students, if the attendance, while
not unusually large, may be taken
as an indication.
The other class, which holds its
meetings at one o'clock every
Thursday, has for its subject,
"Japan." Mr. James Fullerton
Gressitt, an alumnus and former
Y. M. C. A. secretary of this University, has charge of the class. Mr.
Gressitt, having spent the past
seven years in Japan as an educational missionary, is unusually well
equipped to make this a most interesting and instructive course.
Another class for which the officers of the Association hope to
have arrangements soon completed
will be on "North American Problems." The leader will be Mr.
William 0. Weyforth, Jr., who is
a graduate student in political science. "Christianity and Popular
Amusements" will be the text-book
use. More complete information
concerning this class will be given
later.
The Association earnestly invites
all members of the University to
join one of these classes with the
feeling that the student will derive
a great benefit along educational
and religious lines.
The attendance has been very encouraging in view of the recent
organization. However, the Officers
anticipate a decided improvement
in this direction.
The annual Maryland Intercollegiate Missionary Conference will
hold its opening meeting on the
evening of the twenty-sixth of this
month at Goucher College. All
colleges and universities in this
State will send delegates to this
conference, and Secretary Sutton
hopes that Hopkins will be represented creditably and requests that
all men interested should confer
with him as soon as possible.
A fee of one dollar is required
of all delegates to pay the expenses
of the Conference. The meetings,
however, will be open to the public
and one need not he a delegate to
attend.

Prof. Louis Wallis, of Chicago,
who has recently been speaking on
the single tax at various places in
Baltimore, addressed a large audience last Monday night in McCoy Hall on the subject of "Higher
Biblical Criticism."
Professor Wallis gave his view
of the Bible, showing that the Hebrew, and later the Christian religion, has been the enemy of
special privilege and has stood for
justice to the lower classes. The
fight of the Church in the past has
been between Ritual and Justice,
he said; that of the present Church
is between individual worship and
social justice.
After he had finished, counter
arguments were advanced by Dr.
Kelly and Dr. White, of New York,
maintaining the distinction between
economics and religion. A general
discussion ensued, in which most
of the topics of the higher Biblical
criticism were considered.

SUMMER SCHOOL WILL OFFER
COURSES IN GRADUATE WORK

Preparations for the courses to
be given in the fifth year of the
Johns Hopkins Summer School are
already being made, and although
the descriptive catalog will not be
ready before March 1, one important innovation has been announced
in advance.
This innovation, a provision for
graduate courses in the Summer
School, is commented upon in an
editorial in the last edition of the
Alumni Magazine as being the first
to be introduced by the new administration, and as a significant indication of the progressive policy that
is being followed in the carrying on
of University affairs. These courses
are offered in partial fulfillment of
the requirements for the degree of
master of arts. Thus attendance
upon graduate courses in the Summer School for three years will be
considered as a substitute for one
of the two years of study formerly
required of candidates for a master's degree by the Board of University Studies.
The number of departments which
will be included under the provisions of this new arrangement has
not yet been finally decided upon,
but every effort will be made to
provide instruction in every department that is desired by enough students to make up a class of appreciable size. All who are interested in the formation of classes
are therefore requested to communicate with Dr. E. F. Buchner,
who will this season again be the
director of the summer courses.
The plans at present under consideration provide for the extension of
this new policy into ten branches
of graduate study.
The other courses given will be
to a large extent the same that have
proven so very popular in the previous years of the Summer School's
existence. As in the case of graduate studies, special arrangements
will be made for classes desiring to
pursue other studies than those
offered in the regular curriculum.
A full description of the work to
be covered will be found in the
prospectus which will be issued in
the course of the nekt few weeks.

drawn attention to the fact that

The Tocqueville gold medal is

HULLABALOO BOARD IS BUSY
HANDLING ITS CONTRIBUTIONS

MILITARY INSTRUCTION CAMPS
TO BE HELD FOR COLLEGE MEN

During the past week the Hullabaloo Board has had four meetings. These were found to be
necessary to handle the amount of
work with which the Board has
been swamped. On Tuesdays the
Board meets to look over articles
that have been worked up by the
editors during the daily meetings.
So far cuts have been made of
many of the pictures that were
taken earlier in the year. Since
everything will have to be ready for
press within about four or five
Weeks, those who have not ordered
their books had better do so, because the number of books this year
is going to be limited. Anyone
wishing to subscribe may obtain
blanks from any member of the
Board.
This year the book will contain
a number of surprises in the way
of unusual pictures of the University life. The art department has
received some contributions from
some of the members of the other
classes, but it still needs much
more material.
Business Manager Spencer announces that he is fairly well
pleased with the number of subscriptions, but he thinks that the
circulation among the freshmen
class ought to be larger. From
this year on the Board wants the
Hullabaloo to be more of a University book and not so much of
a class book as the former Hullabaloos have been. If each class in
the University will get behind this
book it must certainly be a success.

The Society of the National Reserve Corps has recently launched
a nation-wide campaign among
American colleges to arouse interest in the Government's Student's Military Instruction Camps;
and, among the others, Hopkins
men have been asked to furnish
their quota for the furtherance of
this movement.
The object of the Corps is to
give the young men of the country
opportunity for a short course in
military training. The summer vacation period is selected to enable
students to attend with the least
inconvenience and greatest instructional advantage.
The benefit of these camps to
the nation is that they foster a
patriotic spirit, and spread among
the citizens of the country a more
thorough knowledge of military history, military policy and military
needs. The benefit to the student
is that these camps are certain to
increase his business efficiency, and
hence his economic value through
the habits thus acquired of discipline, obedience, self-control, order,
and command, and the study of
organization and administration as
exemplified in first-class modern
armies.
Now that the country has been
aroused to the fact that the state
of defence of the nation is inadequate, these camps take on especial
importance as furnishing a means
by which a large and well trained
citizen reserve may be built up.
The requisites for admission to
the camps are that students must

Half Mile—Willis and Rosen.
Mile—Willis, Rosen, Hayes, Hutton and Spencer.
High Jump— Wiggins, Tappan
and Connolly.
Shot Put—Connolly.
Pole Vault—Tappan.
Hurdles—Tappan, Binford and
Phondson.
The whole track squad is to be
entered in the meet, but as yet the
rest of the candidates have not been
assigned to any special event.
Freshman Basket-Ball League.

On Monday the reorganized
Freshman
Basket-Ball League
opened its schedule when Team
No. 2 defeated Team No. i by the
score of 20 to 10. The shooting
of Evans, Thurman and Rosenau
were the features of the game.
On Wednesday Team No. 3 defeated Team No. 4 by the close
score of 15 to 13. At the end of
the first half the score was 9 to
4 in favor of No. 4. Witz, Jacobsen, Sullivan and Egerton were the
stars of this game. The following
